question: The electrical supply to the propeller blades for de-icing purposes:

choices.choice: is controlled to give an intermittent supply.
must be taken directly from the APU generator.
must only be selected on for short periods.
is continuous to all blades.

subject: Technical

choices.choice: fitted only to the thin outer sections where maximum ice accretion occurs.
fitted only to the thick inner section where minimum ice accretion occurs.
usually fitted to the thick section but sometimes a second element is fitted to a mid section.
fitted to the complete leading edge.

question: When an aircraft is de-iced prior to departure, if the temperature is 0 C in precipitation, which type of fluid and application method will provide the longest holdover period:

choices.choice: Type I fluid at 100% cold spray application.
Type II fluid diluted to 50% hot spray application.
Type I fluid diluted to 50% hot spray application.
Type II fluid at 100% cold spray application.

subject: Technical

question: The effect of frost on an aircraft:

choices.choice: is to cause an increase in boundary layer energy and so delay the onset of the stall.
can be generally ignored.
has no significant effect on the aerodynamic contour or CL max.
is to cause an increase in the surface roughness which in turn increases skin friction and reduces the kinetic energy of the boundary layer.

subject: Technical

question: In flight airframe icing does not occur:

choices.choice: above 25,000 ft.
above 40,000 ft.
above 35,000 ft.
above 30,000 ft.

subject: Technical

question: The methods used to provide de-icing in flight can be:

choices.choice: mechanical or pneumatic or fluid.
pneumatic or thermal or fluid.
electrically heated or air heated or oil heated.
centrifugally forced or ram air heated.

subject: Technical

question: Ice detectors are used primarily to warn the crew:

choices.choice: that they are approaching airframe icing conditions.
that they are approaching engine icing conditions.
that engine icing conditions now warrant the initiation of the engine system.
that airframe icing conditions exist.

subject: Technical

question: Fluid is delivered to a propeller by:

choices.choice: a centrifugal slipper ring and pipes.
integral passages within the propeller dome.
a small reservoir contained within the spinner.
a slinger ring and pipes.

subject: Technical

question: If an aircraft is to be de-iced prior to departure:

choices.choice: the aircraft can be de-iced with the engines running.
the aircraft can be de-iced with the APU running.
the aircraft can be de-iced with the APU running and the bleed air off.
neither the APU or main engines can be running during the procedure.

subject: Technical

question: With a gas turbine engine, should engine anti-icing be selected “ON”:

choices.choice: whenever the igniters are on.
whenever the IOAT is +10 C or below and the air contains visible moisture.
whenever the TOAT is +10 C or below and it is raining.
whenever the ice detector system warning light comes on.

subject: Technical

choices.choice: the boots remain inflated while the system operates.
the boots are inflated and deflated repeatedly.
vacuum inflates the boots and pressure deflates them repeatedly.
when the boots are fully inflated the pressure is released and they collapse due to their elasticity.

question: When the pneumatic de-icer system is switched off:

choices.choice: the relief valves admit ram air to the boots.
a small flow of hot air continuously flows through the boots.
the dynamic pressure on the leading edge ensures that the boots lie flat.
vacuum deflates the boots to minimise drag.

subject: Technical

choices.choice: use only continuous loads to the elements.
use a cyclic timer.
convert electrical energy to mechanical energy.
transfer power to the elements via a commutator in DC systems.
use only when all other services are switched off.
carry out a load check before starting engines.
use only when the propellers are rotating.
use only when in flight.
feeds hot air along the complete upper wing surface.
feeds the engine exhaust through the leading edge ducts only.
can use air taken from the engine compressor.
relies on heat generated by the kinetic heating effect of the airflow.
only to prevent condensation occurring.
by agitating the window molecules with an AC current.
with a reflective inner coating that prevents fogging.
by passing current across an inner conductive electrical coating.

question: For maximum strength against impact damage pilots windows are:

choices.choice: normally kept to a minimum size.
specially treated during construction.
heated internally to increase their elasticity.
only heated when the IOAT falls below 0 C in precipitation.

subject: Technical

choices.choice: only heated by air from the de-misting fan.
constructed by heat treating the outer surface to reduce glare.
made of sandwich construction with an electrical conductive coating.
made of polarised glass.

question: An aircraft is to be de-iced and then enter the line up for departure. Which de-ice fluid will have the best holdover time at 0 C with precipitation:

choices.choice: type I fluid at 100% cold spray.
a 50%/50% solution of type II fluid hot spray.
a 50%/50% solution of type I fluid hot spray.
type II fluid at 100% cold spray.

subject: Technical
